description: Second term of a two-year sequence designed to integrate real world experiences into various Bioengienering Science courses. It is required for both BSE and BAS majors. It is intended for the spring semester of the Sophomore year.
name: LECTURE

values.comments: This lab course is the second in a two-year sequence aimed at “integrating real world experiences into various BE courses.” The five-week lab period, each six hours long, uses MATLAB extensively.   Students generally found that this course contained “interesting material” covering a “broad assortment of topics” that showed students “what research and BE are about.” Many felt the class had “real-world value,” but that the lab portion of the course was “very different and disjoined” from the lecture. One student expressed his frustration with the suggested reading, calling it “not as helpful” and suggesting that the instructor provide sources for further reading.   Students called Dr. Widenbrant a “great teacher,” but many wished that she had provided examples of good reports from previous years. They stated that the procedures and report instructions were “confusing” and that having both a final project and exam was “excessive.”   Multiple students described this course as “a lot of work” and “extremely time consuming.” Many said that the time commitment “decreased their success in other courses.” They tended to agree that the lab was “stressful” and the pre-lab would take “up to eight hours” to complete. As one student put it, having a report due each week “was like running a race and never getting to breathe.” This is a sophomore year course required for all BE students.   This review is based on the 7 student comments which were submitted.

This lab course is the second in a two-year sequence aimed at “integrating real world experiences into various BE courses.” The five-week lab period, each six hours long, uses MATLAB extensively.   Students generally found that this course contained “interesting material” covering a “broad assortment of topics” that showed students “what research and BE are about.” Many felt the class had “real-world value,” but that the lab portion of the course was “very different and disjoined” from the lecture. One student expressed his frustration with the suggested reading, calling it “not as helpful” and suggesting that the instructor provide sources for further reading.   Students called Dr. Widenbrant a “great teacher,” but many wished that she had provided examples of good reports from previous years. They stated that the procedures and report instructions were “confusing” and that having both a final project and exam was “excessive.”   Multiple students described this course as “a lot of work” and “extremely time consuming.” Many said that the time commitment “decreased their success in other courses.” They tended to agree that the lab was “stressful” and the pre-lab would take “up to eight hours” to complete. As one student put it, having a report due each week “was like running a race and never getting to breathe.” This is a sophomore year course required for all BE students.   This review is based on the 7 student comments which were submitted.

Second term of a two-year sequence designed to integrate real world experiences into various Bioengienering Science courses.   Students generally felt that the class was not as good as its predecessor, BE 209, where students felt they were solving more real-world problems. Students did not find the experiments as engaging or as interesting and instead thought some of them as “unnecessarily long” and “similar to the ones performed in BIOL 121 lab.”   Most students praised Professor Sarkar as a “fair grader” and felt that he was always available and “willing to help” in the lab or to discuss lab reports.   Many students felt that this course was particularly time-consuming, as students devoted a huge amount of time outside class (in addition to 6 hours in lab), cutting into time spent for other classes and extracurriculars. It is required for both BSE and BAS majors. This course is intended for the spring semester of Sophomore year.
